months.summary: In August, students will explore different types of numbers, including real numbers, integers, and rational and irrational numbers. Understanding these concepts is fundamental as it sets the stage for algebraic expressions and equations, which will be covered later.

September will focus on algebraic expressions, helping students learn how to manipulate variables and constants. Solving linear equations will enhance their problem-solving skills. Understanding functions will further their ability to analyze relationships between variables.

This month, students will learn how to graph linear equations on a coordinate plane, understanding the significance of slope and intercepts. They will also tackle systems of equations, which is crucial for solving real-world problems involving multiple conditions.

In November, students will delve into polynomials, learning about their structure and how to perform operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. Factoring polynomials will prepare them for quadratic equations in later months.

topics: **Solving Quadratics by Factoring and Quadratic Formula**
months.summary: December focuses on quadratic equations, where students will learn various methods to solve them, including factoring and using the quadratic formula. They will also explore graphing quadratic functions, deepening their understanding of parabolas.

January will introduce inequalities and absolute values. Students will learn how to solve and graph linear inequalities, which will help them understand ranges of solutions rather than just specific values.

This month will cover exponents and exponential functions, as well as radicals and rational exponents. Students will also learn to work with scientific notation, which is essential in many scientific fields.

In March, students will study probability and statistics, focusing on measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode). They will learn to interpret and analyze data, skills vital for making informed decisions and understanding real-world phenomena.

April will introduce basic concepts of geometry, including properties of shapes, perimeter, area, and volume. These concepts are crucial for spatial reasoning and will be foundational for more advanced geometry topics.

In May, students will explore transformations in geometry, congruence, and similarity. Basic trigonometry will be introduced, which is essential for understanding angles and relationships in various shapes, setting the groundwork for future math courses.
